title: 112_hr6530
content: The Act may be cited as the "Global Free Internet Act of 2012". Congress acknowledges the importance of a single, open, global Internet for the free flow of information and products. Policies should encourage global technology standards, respect user security and privacy, promote innovation, avoid restricting information flow, and support trade in Internet-related goods and services. Certain governments and international bodies are adopting policies contrary to a free, open Internet, including mandating unique technology standards, sponsoring unauthorized access to networks, blocking Internet communications, and monitoring Internet use. Certain governments and international bodies are adopting policies against Internet-based services and content from other countries, monitoring Internet use in a way that restricts privacy and freedom, and imposing market access requirements that discriminate against foreign Internet-related goods and services. These actions threaten the interests of the United States by facilitating foreign governments' attempts to restrict the free flow of information on the Internet, promoting conflicting "national Internets," and harming US workers and businesses. The curr_chunk highlights the negative impacts of certain policies on the United States, including harming US workers and businesses, undermining the industrial base, and risking the utility of the Internet for communication and commerce. The curr_chunk establishes the creation of a Task Force on the Global Internet. The Task Force on the Global Internet is established within the executive branch, hosted by the Department of Commerce. The Task Force consists of four individuals with expertise in Internet policy and civil liberties, nominated by the public and appointed by the President, and the leader of the majority party in the Senate. The Task Force on the Global Internet, established within the executive branch and hosted by the Department of Commerce, consists of individuals with expertise in Internet policy and civil liberties. Members are appointed by various government officials for renewable terms not exceeding 3 years. The Task Force on the Global Internet, established within the executive branch and hosted by the Department of Commerce, consists of individuals with expertise in Internet policy and civil liberties. Members are appointed by various government officials for renewable terms not exceeding 3 years. The Task Force may request personnel or services from Federal agencies to assist in responding to foreign and domestic government policies that burden international trade in Internet-related goods, services, and content. The Task Force on the Global Internet, established by the executive branch and hosted by the Department of Commerce, aims to prevent threats to the open, global nature of the Internet. It consults with civil society groups, coordinates federal departments, prepares reports, holds public hearings, and appoints a civilian Task Force member to lead and serve as a point of contact. The Task Force on the Global Internet, established by the executive branch and hosted by the Department of Commerce, appoints a civilian Task Force member to lead and serve as a point of contact for its activities. SEC. 4. REPORT AND ACTION PLAN TO THE PRESIDENT AND CONGRESS. The Task Force must annually report to the President and Congress on acts, policies, or practices that hinder fair market access in Internet-related trade and technology standards. The Task Force must annually report to the President and Congress on acts, policies, or practices that hinder fair market access in Internet-related trade and technology standards. The report should estimate the trade-distorting impact on United States commerce and set forth a strategy for Federal departments and agencies to respond to these measures. It should also designate priority concerns and provide information on actions taken in response to previous reports. The Task Force is required to annually report on hindrances to fair market access in Internet-related trade and technology standards. Reports may include a classified annex if deemed necessary. Public participation is encouraged through notices, public hearings, and a dedicated website. Coordination with executive branch departments, agencies, and civil society is essential. The Task Force must consult with relevant executive branch departments and agencies, share information with civil society groups, and consider input from various sources, including the United States Trade Representative. The report and action plan will be published in the Federal Register, excluding information transmitted under subsection (b). SEC. 5. The United States Trade Representative will initiate investigations and take actions against foreign governments or international bodies for priority concerns identified in annual reports. SEC. 6. The Federal Trade Commission and Department of Justice will conduct reviews and investigations. SEC. 6. The Federal Trade Commission and the Attorney General will review and investigate acts, policies, or practices that may violate antitrust laws. The term "antitrust laws" includes the Clayton Act and section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Task Force is required to submit a report assessing existing trade agreements related to Internet trade, technology standards, Internet security, information flow, and user interests. It also recommends modifications or new agreements to achieve these objectives. Congress believes future trade agreements should include these goals. The United States' negotiating objectives for trade agreements should align with specified goals. Reports may include a classified annex if deemed necessary. The Task Force must seek public participation, coordinate with relevant departments, and consult with civil society groups on Internet policy and civil liberties. The Task Force must consult civil society groups with expertise in Internet policy and civil liberties, consider information from various sources, and publish the report and action plan in the Federal Register. The Task Force will coordinate with various entities for standards-related training and establish a process for receiving input from businesses and organizations.
